Heads or tails? On today‚Äôs #WeeklyFluff, lounging is an art form with Nymphadora (@oridisia_cats), an Oriental shorthair who rules the roost.‚Å£
‚Å£
Video by @oridisia_cats

#HelloFrom Vinicunca, or Rainbow Mountain, located in the Peruvian Andes. We‚Äôre dreaming of a trek across this multicolored landscape that‚Äôs 17,000 feet (5,200 meters) above sea level.

Photo by @moonmountainman

Artist Tina Yu (@tina.yu.artist) describes her clay creature style as ‚Äúdouble c: cute and creepy.‚Äù But they‚Äôre more than fairy tale characters ‚Äî Tina‚Äôs creations represent empowered animal advocates ‚Äúreborn into a new colorful fantasy world, where there‚Äôs no pain and suffering, and they can live happily ever after.‚Äù‚Å£
‚Å£
‚ÄúI think the most special moment is seeing all the characters I come up with in my head come to ‚Äòlife,‚Äô‚Äù says Tina. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve learned how to express myself through my artwork in an emotional way. By taking inspiration from people, things and memories that are personal to me, I feel like I‚Äôve found my own identity in art.‚Äù #ThisWeekOnInstagram‚Å£
‚Å£
Video by @tina.yu.artist

For Naoto Hattori (@naoto_hattori), ‚Äúthe soul is in the details.‚Äù His tiny acrylic paintings are the depiction of his lucid dreams. ‚ÄúI am fascinated by the mysterious sensation of being able to visualize things from memories,‚Äù says the Japanese artist. ‚ÄúThe stream of consciousness flows continuously without end, like the flow of a river. I look at the distorted faces reflected in that river and draw them just as they are,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúThey may appear as asymmetrical and distorted large-eyed characters, but actually, they are real objects in the world of my memories.‚Äù #ThisWeekOnInstagram‚Å£
‚Å£
Illustration by @naoto_hattori

Singer Troye Sivan (@troyesivan) is really missing coffee shops these days. While sheltering in place, he‚Äôs become his family‚Äôs barista. üôå 
#TakeABreak with Troye in Australia as he brews up a coffee drink for his dad.

This is Peach. He is artist Michele Bisaillon‚Äôs (@michel_e_b) 14-year-old cat‚Ä¶ and muse. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve been taking photos of him since day one, but after I started taking photos with mirrors, I felt the whole thing click,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúThe props I use with my cat represent a normal human experience in the mirror. We put on our hats and our glasses and we check ourselves out. We take ourselves in. We check our reflections out first so we can get an idea of what others may see in us.‚Äù #ThisWeekOnInstagram‚Å£
‚Å£
Photo by @michel_e_b

10/10 would recommend these posts. ‚ú®‚Å£üê∂üç∞‚Å£

For actress and activist Yara Shahidi (@yarashahidi), there are three themes that are helping her through these uncertain times: stillness, creativity and change.‚Å£
‚ú®üí´‚ú®‚Å£
‚ÄúWhether it be your hair or your goals, change is so important. This is the perfect time to remind ourselves that no action is too small by any means. It is collective action that matters. And it‚Äôs the fact that you woke up and decided to take action to begin with.‚Äù‚Å£
‚Å£
Follow Yara‚Äôs advice and #TakeABreak with us. You‚Äôll be glad you did. üíì

Nothing to see here. Just some üòç alpacas at sunrise, a üíØ morning routine and some new üå± friends.‚Å£

On today‚Äôs #WeeklyFluff, meet Maya (@mayapolarbear) and her homespun litter. ‚ÄúSamoyeds have a thick undercoat and shed one or two times per year,‚Äù says her human, Lingli. ‚ÄúI took this picture after brushing Maya. I thought it would be funny to draw little faces on the fur to make it look like many puppies.‚Äù üê∂ ‚Å£
‚Å£
Photo illustration by @mayapolarbear

#HelloFrom Swedish Lapland, a province in northernmost Sweden. We‚Äôre currently dreaming of this magical mirrored treehouse that all passersby (including birds) can enjoy, since it‚Äôs covered in a special film, visible to any flying friends. ‚Å£‚Å£‚Å£ ‚Å£‚Å£‚Å£
Photo by @charlysavely
